Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of a Liquid Handling Robot and a High-throughput Real-time PCR Thermocycler for Genetics and Genomics Research at UND
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This Major Research Instrumentation-Recovery and Reinvestment (MRI-R2) award funds the acquisition of an integrated set of instruments to enable medium to high-throughput analysis of DNA, RNA, and protein at the University of North Dakota (UND). A high capacity PCR unit, tissue homogenizer, and associated liquid handling robot greatly enhance the UND infrastructure to support biological research. The instrumentation enables cutting-edge research training and classroom education in engineering and life sciences at the interface of disciplines, i.e., ecological genomics, systems biology, and the human-robot interface. The research is unified by an emphasis on the genetic, epigenetic, and genomic bases of biological responses to environmental stressors, including abiotic factors like temperature, atmospheric gases, humidity, and heavy metals and biotic factors like herbivores and nutrition. The influence of high-throughput technologies reaches beyond pure research to provide significant new educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. Such training opportunities are especially important for students who are demographically underrepresented in the life sciences and engineering. The nature of modern research is epitomized by the newly acquired instruments, stemming from interdisciplinary interactions among engineers, computer scientists, physicists, chemists, and biologists. The instrumentation allows students to gain valuable experiences, and may allow for the attraction or formation of new companies and higher paying jobs to the area, which in turn helps retain the state's talent and brainpower. Results from the studies enabled by the new equipment will be disseminated by student and faculty presentations at regional and national meetings, and through publication in peer-reviewed journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Activities

This NSF grant allowed acquisition of an integrated set of instruments for medium to high-throughput analysis of DNA, RNA, and protein at the University of North Dakota. The instrumentation includes 1) a Tissue Lyser II for simultaneous homogenization of up to 192 biological samples, 2) a Biomek FXP liquid handling robot with microplate reader to scale-up various biological assays to 96-well and 384-well plates, and 3) a CFX384 real-time PCR thermocycler for genotyping DNA and measuring gene expression. The robot is arranged in a flexible configuration, allowing automation of many protocols. Key capabilities include DNA, RNA, and protein isolation and quantification; cDNA synthesis; PCR setup for DNA sequencing, genotyping, and gene expression assays; protein ELISA; receptor-ligand binding assays; and fluorescent labeling of cDNA for downstream microarray hybridization.

 

The instrumentation has directly facilitated research on the genetic and genomic bases of biological responses to abiotic factors like temperature, atmospheric gases, as well as biotic factors like herbivores and the impact of genetic mutations on animal development. The instruments have also provided training opportunities for a post-doctoral fellow, several graduate students, and numerous undergraduate students in biology and engineering.

 

Intellectual Merit 

We have used the instrumentation described above to analyze hundreds of genes in thousands of samples. Major advances have been made in our understanding of the gene regulatory networks that underlie temperature-dependent sex determination, which has implications for a wide range of species that may be adversely affected by climate change. Significant progress has also been made with regard to the effects of hypoxia on gene expression and cardiovascular development in reptiles and birds. Additional studies have examined the impact of heavy metals on development of the nervous system in zebrafish. The instrumentation has also been used to elucidate the role vascular endothelial growth factor isoforms play in the regulation of forebrain development. Preliminary studies have been started that will implement high throughput techniques in epigenetics research.

 

Broader Impact

The instrumentation has provided hands-on training and educational opportunities for a wide range of students, including individuals from underrepresented groups like Native Americans, women, and students from a rural state. Biology and engineering students have been given practical classroom experience using state of the art technologies for high-throughput analysis of biological molecules. Many undergraduate students involved in research in the PI and CoPI’s laboratories have gone on to professional or graduate school.

 

Ongoing Research and Educational Activities

We continue to use the instruments on the projects described above, extensions of these projects, as well as new collaborations stemming from interactions among users of the instrumentation. We keep using the instruments as an integral component of classes in molecular biology and mechanical engineering.
